@himanshug I'm not hitting it with the new kafka-indexing-service.
We have an internal product which is similar to kafka, but with ability to rewind from old timestamp(kafka can only rewind from offset which is difficult to associate offset with a specified time point).
We have written a druid extension to read from it and remember the checkpoint after segment handoff.
Sometimes, we want to enlarge segmentGranularity to reduce segments number to lessen broker memory pressure, then we rewind from old time and rebuild segments (usually because we found the segmentGranularity is not properly configed).
The best way to resolve this issue is that we use CustomVersioningPolicy to always pass new timestamp as new version in our extension.
But we still think it is worth making broker can recover from "overlap error" by killing the new task, otherwise, all brokers are down in case someone else using druid hits this issue by mistake.

Basically, there are some preconditions to hit this issue:
1. enlarge segmentGranularity, like from hour to day
2. using the default IntervalStartVersioningPolicy
3. can rewind from old data timestamp to create the same interval start as version, like 2016-10-31T00:00:00.000+08:00
Also see: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-user/CmAgH897WiU
Great! thanks a lot @gianm!

Also, as a general comment, before the overlord and coordinator are merged, I'd like to see the Helper stuff go into an extensible form.

For metadata, another option would be to have the coordinator have that information and the brokers to cache it from there.  It could have a fallback that causes it to update its local state based on segment metadata queries if it's having trouble loading from the coordinator (or through a `desc` SQL command or something)

üëç
I moved the PostgreSQL compat stuff out of this PR, since it barely works and it was clogging up the diff.

Hmm after thinking about this some more I wonder if it's something we really want to support. Maybe having this query fail is OK, and it should actually fail with a more descriptive error. The reason is that naming output fields `__time` is problematic for features like,
- nested queries: If the inner query has granularity "hour" and also has a dimension with outputName `__time`, and the outer query filters or groups on `__time`, is that referring to the timestamp of the inner rows or is it referring to the inner dimension named `__time`?
- having specs: If a query has a metric with output name `__time`, and a having spec filters on `__time`, is that referring to the timestamp of the rows or to the metric named `__time`?

Currently I believe for nested queries it refers to the timestamp but for having specs it refers to the metric named `__time`. This is inconsistent and weird and I think there's the best answer is to disallow dimensions or metrics with output names of `__time`.

You can see all of these issues come from the fact that groupBy results have anonymous timestamps in addition to actual named fields coming from dims and metrics and postaggregators. "Higher level" things like having specs and nested queries can access the timestamp by calling it `__time`, but that ends up shadowing any similarly named field from a dim or metric or postaggregator.

As a separate but related issue, I think nothing is really stopping anyone from defining a dimension and metric with the same output name. We should detect and fail on that at the constructor level, since otherwise one will clobber the other.

Maybe since this used to work, we can take the attitude that for 0.9.x that the behavior is that you are allowed to have a dimension or metric with name `__time`, and it will be returned to you just fine in the query result, _but_ "higher level" Druid constructs like having specs and outer queries will not be able to see it. Instead, they'll see the anonymous timestamp of the row. I think this matches how 0.9.1.1 worked.

In 0.10.0 I'd like to make it so naming something `__time` just fails outright.

I suggested an alternate fix in #3685.

I also raised #3687 for discussing what to do about the remaining issues with `__time` and groupBy, and #3686 for 0.9.3 with validation of the "separate but related issue" that dimensions/metrics/postaggs could collide.
Closing for now since this will conflict with #3685.
Closing in favor of #3685

@himanshug New InputFormat should wrap any InputFormats to support various split types like ORC, parquet, or plain text with various delimiters and I thought it is too much. Any advice or suggestion plz.
I followed the comments from @fjy and move PartitionPathSpec specific code to that class as possible.

the most empty location may fail because of IO failure, most like in two cases:
1. druid don't have the write access to this disk, most likely the administrator doesn't config it correctly
2. disk failure, druid can't read/write to this disk anymore.

If we don't retry with other locations, the next time druid call loadSegment, it still use the failed location(it is still the most empty one because no new segment can be added to this location), and it won't success unless administrator remove this location and restart historical. @leventov

This needs to attribute the original codebase

Hrm, yeah, I can believe I can likely be quoted as saying we don't want coordinators to query.  Though, at this point in time, I could be convinced that as long as the coordinator is not actively involved in the primary query path, that would be good enough.

My primary concern with the updating is that you are going to generate load on the cluster for every single broker.  While it's arguable if the load is a significant amount, the fact that it's a linear amount of load is what bothers me and the suggestion to consolidate on the coordinator was an attempt at making it a constant amount of load.  If you can think of another way to make it a constant amount of load, I'd also be down with that.

@kaijianding it was discussed among the devs and we believe broker making the assumption about "different segments sets having different versions, and it should fail otherwise" is there by design and does not need to be changed/fixed.

however, in the long terms, we might want to make updates to handle the situation more gracefully and not getting into a corrupted state after above failure where broker stops accepting queries altogether.

Thanks for the review and your time, but now I'd like to close this PR.  SchemaRepo is a dead technology.  I actually suggest dropping SchemaRepo support entirely.
- Druid now supports Schema Registry that is the standard in Kafka community.
- SchemaRepo has no significant updates since January 2015.
- The proprietary schema ID header means no compatible projects unless they are specifically developed for this extension.
- The assumption that the schema subject and Kafka topic should match is also specific to this extension.
@navis Could you please remove the comparator stuff, or at least split it into a different PR? (doesn't seem related to the math expression stuff)

@leventov @dclim @fjy @gianm
